title: How to Use a Heat Gun to Dry Paint

steps.title: Plug in your heat gun and set the temperature to 450–750 °F (232–399 °C).
steps.content: Plug in your heat gun and set the temperature to 450–750 °F (232–399 °C). Turn the heat gun on and use the buttons on the gun to increase or decrease the temperature. Start at the lower end of the temperature range and increase the temperature gradually as you work if needed. Avoid increasing the temperature over 750 °F (399 °C) or you could end up boiling and peeling the paint off instead of drying it. [1] X Research source Any heat gun with adjustable temperature settings will work for drying paint. Heat guns work best on hard interior and exterior painted surfaces, like painted walls and wooden furniture. Avoid using a heat gun to dry paint on paper or canvas since it could ruin the surface. Instead, try using a hairdryer to quickly dry artwork. [2] X Research source Refer to the manual that came with your heat gun if you’re not sure how to adjust the temperature setting.

steps.title: Hold the heat gun at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) away from the paint.
steps.content: Hold the heat gun at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) away from the paint. If you hold it any closer, you could damage the surface and cause the paint to peel off. As you’re working, make sure you continue to hold the heat gun at a safe distance from the paint. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Aim the heat gun nozzle at the paint while continuously moving it around.
steps.content: Aim the heat gun nozzle at the paint while continuously moving it around. Point the nozzle that the hot air is blowing out of directly at the paint you’re trying to dry. Keep the heat gun moving at all times so you’re not heating one area for too long. Use back and forth or up and down motions as you work your way across the surface you’re drying. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Continue blowing hot air on the paint until it’s dry.
steps.content: Continue blowing hot air on the paint until it’s dry. The amount of time it takes the paint to dry will depend on the type of paint, how thick it is, and how large of an area you’re working with. It could take you around 10 minutes to dry a 1 ft × 2 ft (0.30 m × 0.61 m) area of paint, so plan accordingly. [5] X Research source If you don’t have the time or energy to fully dry the surface you’re working on, using a heat gun can still be an effective way to speed up your paint’s drying time. You can dry it as much as you can with the heat gun, then let it finish air drying the rest of the way.

steps.title: Make sure your work area is free of flammable materials.
steps.content: Make sure your work area is free of flammable materials. Heat guns produce extremely hot air that can cause a fire or explosion if it comes into contact with flammable materials, like aerosol paint canisters, paint thinner, acetone, and gasoline. Before you turn on your heat gun, double-check that there aren’t any flammable materials lying around near the surface you’re working on. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Wear the proper safety gear while handling a heat gun.
steps.content: Wear the proper safety gear while handling a heat gun. You should always wear safety goggles and gloves when you use a heat gun to protect your eyes and hands. Avoid wearing loose clothing since it could get in the way of the nozzle and catch fire. [7] X Research source If you have long hair, tie it back before you use the heat gun.

steps.title: Don’t place the heat gun nozzle directly against the surface you’re drying.
steps.content: Don’t place the heat gun nozzle directly against the surface you’re drying. Not only can this damage the surface and cause the paint to peel off, it can also block the heat gun’s air flow and cause it to overheat and catch fire. [8] X Research source For the purpose of drying paint, you shouldn’t need to hold the nozzle closer than 2 inches (5.1 cm) from the surface.

steps.title: Avoid touching the nozzle or aiming the heat gun at yourself.
steps.content: Avoid touching the nozzle or aiming the heat gun at yourself. The air coming out of a heat gun can get extremely hot and cause serious burns. Never aim the nozzle at yourself or anything besides the surface you’re drying. You should also never touch the nozzle where the hot air comes out since it can get extremely hot. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Turn the heat gun off before setting it down.
steps.content: Turn the heat gun off before setting it down. Placing a heat gun down while it’s still on and hot is a fire hazard. When you’re done using the heat gun, or if you need to take a break from drying your paint, turn the heat gun off and set it down upright so the nozzle is pointing up and not leaning on anything. [10] X Research source Your model of heat gun may have a cool-down setting that you can put it on when you’re not using it.
